Suggestion that two or more operations in the specified class or interface have the same signature, which will prevent valid code generation.

13.13.5. Reduce Operations on <artifact>

Suggestion that the artifact (class or interface) has too many operations for a good design, and is at risk of becoming a design bottleneck.

13.14. Code Generation

Critics concerning code generation in ArgoUML.

The current version of ArgoUML has one critic in this category.

13.14.1. Change Multiple Inheritance to interfaces

Suggestion that a class has multiple generalizations, which is permitted by UML, but cannot be generated into Java code, because Java does not support multiple inheritance.

13.15. Stereotypes

Critics concerning stereotypes in ArgoUML.

The current version of ArgoUML has no critics in this category.

13.16. Inheritance

Critics concerning generalization and specialization in ArgoUML.

The current version of ArgoUML has ten critics in this category.

13.16.1. Revise Attribute Names to Avoid Conflict

This critic is discussed under an earlier design issues category (see Section 13.4.2).

13.16.2. Remove <class>'s Circular Inheritance

Suggestion that a class inherits from itself, through a chain of generalizations, which is not permitted.

Caution

This critic is marked inactive by default in the current release of ArgoUML (the only one so marked). It will not trigger unless made active.

13.16.3. Class Must be Abstract

This critic is discussed under an earlier design issues category (see Section 13.13.2).

13.16.4. Remove final keyword or remove subclasses

Suggestion that a class that is final has specializations, which is not permitted in UML.

13.16.5. Illegal Generalization

Suggestion that there is a generalization between artifacts of different UML metaclasses, which is not permitted.

Caution

It is not clear that such a generalization can be created within ArgoUML. It probably indicates that the diagram was created by loading a corrupt project, with an XMI file describing such a generalization, possibly created by a tool other than ArgoUML.

13.16.6. Remove Unneeded Realizes from <class>

Suggestion that the specified class has a realization relationship both directly and indirectly to the same interface (by realization from two interfaces, one of which is a generalization of the other for example). Good design deprecates such duplication.

13.16.7. Define Concrete (Sub)Class

Suggestion that a class is abstract with no concrete subclasses, and so can never be realized.

13.16.8. Define Class to Implement <interface>

Suggestion that the interface referred to has no influence on the running system, since it is never implemented by a class.

13.16.9. Change Multiple Inheritance to interfaces

This critic is discussed under an earlier design issues category (see Section 13.14.1).

13.16.10. Make Edge More Visible

This critic is discussed under an earlier design issues category (see Section 13.7.14).

13.17. Containment

Critics concerning containment in ArgoUML, that is where one artifact forms a component part of another.

The current version of ArgoUML has six critics in this category.

13.17.1. Remove Circular Composition

Suggestion that there is a series of composition relationships (associations with black diagrams) that form a cycle, which is not permitted.

13.17.2. Duplicate Parameter Name

Suggestion that a parameter list to an operation or event has two or more parameters with the same name, which is not permitted.

13.17.3. Multiple Aggregate Roles

Suggestion that more than one end of an association is aggregate or composite. At most one end should have multiplicity of any sort.

13.17.4. Aggregate Role in N-way Association (Second Version)

Suggestion that more than one end of an association is aggregate or composite. At most one end should have multiplicity of any sort.

Caution

This appears to duplicate the critic Multiple Aggregate Roles within this design category (see Section 13.17.3 and the critic of the same name under the modularity design issue (see Section 13.11.1).

13.17.5. Wrap DataType

This critic is discussed under an earlier design issues category (see Section 13.3.1).

13.17.6. Import Parameter Type into Class

Suggestion that the type of a parameter used within an operation of a class is not visible.

Warning

It is not clear how this can ever be caused within ArgoUML. In any case this critic can never trigger in the current implementation of ArgoUML.

Chapter 14. ArgoUML Top Level Artifact Reference

Table of Contents

14.1 Introduction
14.2 The Model
14.2.1 Model Details Tabs
14.2.2 Model Properties
14.3 Datatype
14.3.1 Datatype Details Tabs
14.3.2 Datatype Properties
14.4 Stereotypes
14.4.1 Stereotype Details Tabs
14.4.2 Stereotype Properties
14.5 ArgoUML Diagrams
14.5.1 Diagram Details Tabs
14.5.2 Diagram Properties

14.1. Introduction

This chapter describes each artifact that can be created within ArgoUML. The chapter covers top-level “general” artifacts. The following chapters (see Chapter 15. ArgoUML Use Case Diagram Artifact Reference through Chapter 21. ArgoUML Deployment Diagram Artifact Reference) cover each of the ArgoUML diagrams.

There is a close relationship between this material and the properties tab of the details pane (see Section 10.4). That section covers properties in general, in this chapter they are linked to specific artifacts.

14.2. The Model

The model is the top level artifact within ArgoUML. In the UML meta-model it is a sub-class of package. In many respects within ArgoUML it behaves similarly to a package (see Section 16.2).

Note

ArgoUML is restricted to one model within the tool.

Caution

In principle you can add a model to a class diagram using the context sensitive (button 2) pop up menu Add To Diagramfrom the navigation pane. However this is very demanding of memory and may cause a problem with ArgoUML running out of memory.

Where standard data types, classes and packages are loaded (the default, see Chapter 22. ArgoUML Built In DataTypes, Classes, Intefaces and Stereotypes), these are sub-packages of the model.

Note

In version 0.9.6 of ArgoUML these sub-packages are not initially visible from the model property pane as owned packages. However if you use the data type navigator from a suitable pane, you can navigate up to the model, and thereafter that data type's sub-packages will appear.

14.2.1. Model Details Tabs

The details tabs that are active for the model are described in Table 14.1. Details tabs for the model.

Note

The Style tab is grayed out, since the model typically has no representation on a diagram (see the caution above).

Table 14.1. Details tabs for the model

TabMeaning
ToDoItem

Standard tab.

Properties

See Table 14.2. Property tool bar for the model and Table 14.3. Property fields for the model below.

Documentation

Standard tab.

Source

Standard tab. This contains a template package declaration appropriate to the entire model. In the future this would be part of the code generation activity.

Constraints

Standard tab. There are no standard constraints defined for Model within the UML meta-model.

Tagged Values

Standard tab. In the UML meta-model, Model has the following standard tagged values defined.

  • derived (from the superclass, ModelElement). Values true, meaning the class is redundant—it can be formally derived from other elements, or false meaning it cannot.

    Note

    Derived models still have their value in analysis to introduce useful names or concepts, and in design to avoid re-computation.

Note

The UML Element metaclass from which all other artifacts are derived includes the tagged element documentation which is handled by the documentation tab under ArgoUML

14.2.2. Model Properties

The property tab tool bar for the model is described in Table 14.2. Property tool bar for the model.

Table 14.2. Property tool bar for the model

ButtonIconMeaning
Go up

Navigate up through the package structure of the model.

Go back

Navigate back to the previous artifact.

Warning

This feature is currently broken within ArgoUML and there is no guarantee where (if anywhere) this button will take you.

Go forward

Navigate forward to the next artifact.

Warning

This feature is currently broken within ArgoUML and there is no guarantee where (if anywhere) this button will take you.

Add class

This creates a new class (see Section 16.5) within the model (which appears on no diagram), navigating immediately to the properties tab for that class.

Tip

Whilst it can make sense to create classes this way, it is usually a lot clearer to create them within diagrams where you want them.

Add interface

This creates a new interface (see Section 16.14) within the model (which appears on no diagram), navigating immediately to the properties tab for that interface.

Tip

Whilst it can make sense to create interfaces this way, it is usually a lot clearer to create them within diagrams where you want them.

Add datatype

This creates a new data type (see Section 14.3) within the model (which appears on no diagram), navigating immediately to the properties tab for that datatype.

Add stereotype

This creates a new stereotype (see Section 14.4) within the model, navigating immediately to the properties tab for that stereotype.

Add actor

This creates a new actor (see Section 15.2) within the model (which appears on no diagram), navigating immediately to the properties tab for that actor.

Tip

Whilst it can make sense to create actors this way, it is usually a lot clearer to create them within diagrams where you want them.

Add use case

This creates a new use case (see Section 15.3) within the model (which appears on no diagram), navigating immediately to the properties tab for that use case.

Tip

Whilst it can make sense to create use cases this way, it is usually a lot clearer to create them within diagrams where you want them.

Add subpackage

This creates a new sub-package (see Section 16.2) within the model (which appears on no diagram), navigating immediately to the properties tab for that package.

Tip

Whilst it can make sense to create sub-packages of the model this way, it is usually a lot clearer to create them within diagrams where you want them.

Add generalization

This creates a new generalization (see Section 15.6 and Section 16.13) within the model (which appears on no diagram), navigating immediately to the properties tab for that generalization.

Tip

Whilst it can make sense to create generalizations this way, it is usually a lot clearer to create them within diagrams where you want them.

Add realization

This should create a new realization (i.e. an abstraction with stereotype realize—see Section 16.15) within the model (which appears on no diagram).

Warning

This appears to be broken in the current release of ArgoUML. Even if it did work, it would be of limited value, since the abstraction property sheet has no mechanism for adding supplier and client artifacts.

Delete

This has no effect—it is meaningless to delete the model!

The fields on the property tab for models are described in Table 14.3. Property fields for the model.

Table 14.3. Property fields for the model

FieldMeaning
Name

Text box. The name of the model. The name of a model, like all packages, is by convention all lower case.

Note

The default name supplied to a new model by ArgoUML, untitledModel, is thus erroneous and guarantees that ArgoUML always starts up with at least one problem being reported by the design critics.

Stereotype

Drop down selector. Model is provided by default with the UML standard stereotypes for model (systemModel and metamodel) and package (facade, framework, stub), as well as the stereotypes for models and packages in the UML standard profiles for software development process (use-case model, analysis model, design model, implementation model, use case package and analysis service package). ArgoUML also provides the additional stereotypes, machine, organization and person.

Note

A number of standard stereotypes are currently missing from ArgoUML: topLevel (from package), use case system, analysis system, analysis package (all three from the software development process profile).

Caution

ArgoUML provides the stereotype realize for models and packages. This appears to be an error, since this stereotype properly belongs to the Association metaclass.

Stereotyping models is a useful thing, although it is of limited value in ArgoUML where you have only a single model.

Navigate Stereotype

icon. If a stereotype has been selected, this will navigate you to the stereotype property panel (see Section 14.4).

Namespace

Text box. Records the namespace for the model. This is the package hierarchy. However since the model is at the top of the hierarchy in ArgoUML, this box is always empty.

Modifiers

Check box, with entries Abstract, Final and Root.

  • abstract is used to declare that this model cannot be instantiated, but must always be specialized.

    Tip

    The meaning of abstract applied to a model is not that clear. It might mean that the model contains interfaces or abstract classes without realizations. Since ArgoUML only permits one model, this is not a meaningful box to check.

  • final indicates that this model can have no further subpackages, while root indicates it is the top level model.

    Tip

    Within ArgoUML root only meaningfully applies to the Model, since all packages sit within the model. In the absence of the topLevel stereotype, this could be used to emphasize that the Model is at the top level.

Derived

Text box. Lists any derived class. Meaningless for a model.

Extends

Text box. Lists any use case that is extended by this model. Meaningless for a model.

Implements

Text area. Lists any models for which this model is the realization. Of little value within ArgoUML, since multiple models are not permitted.

It is possible to add realizations from this menu, although since there is no way to add a model to the other end of the abstraction, it is meaningless. Button 1 click allows you to navigate to them and button 2 click gives a pop up menu with options to Open, Add, Delete, Move Up and Move Down (see Generalizations for examples of how these operations are used).

Owned Elements

Text area. A hierarchical listing of the packages, classes, interfaces, datatypes, actors, use cases, associations, generalizations and stereotypes within the model. For each of these types of artifact, where there is at least one example in the model, a folder icon is shown.

Button 1 double click on the folder icon () opens the folder to reveal the artifacts owned under that category.

Button 1 click on any of the revealed artifacts yields navigates to that artifact.

Button 1 double click on an open folder (with artifacts displayed) will close the folder and hide the artifacts.

Alternatively, Button 2 double click on any item gives a pop up menu.

  • Add. This option creates a new artifact of the specified type within the model, and navigates to that item.

    Note

    The item is placed under its relevant folder, irrespective of where the pop up menu is revealed. So button 2 lick on Actor folder and selection of Add/Package will place the new package under the Package folder, not the Actor folder.

    This is the only menu option actually available to the model (the others apply to packages within the model, see Section 16.2).

    Tip

    It is often far easier to add artifacts by drawing them on the relevant diagram in the editing pane.

  • Delete. This is always grayed out for a model.

  • Go. This is always grayed out for a model.

  • Open. This is always grayed out for a model.

14.3. Datatype

Datatypes can be thought of as simple classes. They have no attributes, and any operations on them must have no side-effects. A useful analogy is primitive datatypes in a language like Java. The integer “3” stands on its own—it has no inner structure. There are operations (for example addition) on the integers, but when I perform 3 + 4 the result is a new number, “3” and “4” are unchanged by the exercise.

Within UML 1.3, DataType is a sub-class of the Classifier metaclass. It embraces the predefined primitive types (byte, char, double, float, int, long and short), the predefined enumeration, boolean and user defined enumeration types.

Note

void is implemented as a class rather than a datatype within ArgoUML

Within ArgoUML new datatypes may be created using the New datatype button on the property tabs of the model and packages (in which case the new datatype is restricted in scope to the package), as well as the properties tab for datatype..

You can navigate to existing property types via the NavClass button on any property sheet that has a Type drop-down (for example attribute or parameter).

Caution

UML 1.3 allows user defined datatypes to be placed on class diagrams. This is not permitted in ArgoUML.

14.3.1. Datatype Details Tabs

The details tabs that are active for datatypes are described in Table 14.4. Details tabs for datatype.

Table 14.4. Details tabs for datatype

TabMeaning
ToDoItem

Standard tab.

Properties

See Table 14.5. Property tool bar for package and Table 14.6. Property fields for datatype below.

Documentation

Standard tab.

Source

Standard tab, but with no effect. In a future version of ArgoUML the Attributes and Operations tick boxes will control the display of literals and operations defined for the datatype.

Source

Standard tab. Unused. One would expect a class declaration for the new datatype to support code generation.

Constraints

Standard tab. There are no standard constraints defined for Datatype (or Enumeration within the UML metamodel.

Tagged Values

Standard tab. In the UML metamodel, Datatype has the following standard tagged values defined.

  • persistence (from the superclass, Classifier). Values transitory, indicating state is destroyed when an instance is destroyed or persistent, marking state is preserved when an instance is destroyed.

    Tip

    Since user defined datatypes are enumerations, they have no state to preserve, and the value of this tagged value is irrelevant.

  • semantics (from the superclass, Classifier). The value is a specification of the semantics of the datatype.

  • derived (from the superclass, ModelElement). Values true, meaning the class is redundant—it can be formally derived from other elements, or false meaning it cannot.

    Tip

    Whilst formally available, a derived datatype does not have an obvious value, and so datatypes should always be marked with derived=false.

Note

The UML Element metaclass from which all other artifacts are derived includes the tagged element documentation which is handled by the documentation tab under ArgoUML

14.3.2. Datatype Properties

The property tab tool bar for datatypes is described in Table 14.5. Property tool bar for package.

Table 14.5. Property tool bar for package

ButtonIconMeaning
Go up

Navigate up through the package structure.

Go back

Navigate back to the previous artifact.

Warning

This feature is currently broken within ArgoUML and there is no guarantee where (if anywhere) this button will take you.

Go forward

Navigate forward to the next artifact.

Warning

This feature is currently broken within ArgoUML and there is no guarantee where (if anywhere) this button will take you.

New datatype

This creates a new datatype (see Section 16.5) within the same package as the current datatype.

Tip

Whilst it can make sense to create datatypes this way, it can be clearer to create them within the package or model where you want them.

Add enumeration literal

This creates a new enumeration literal within the datatype, navigating immediately to the properties tab for that literal.

Caution

ArgoUML does not actually have a separate concept of a literal. The navigation will take you to the property sheet for an attribute of a class (see Section 16.6). When defining a literal, all that matters is its name. Other parts of the attribute property sheet should be ignored.

Delete

This deletes the datatype from the model.

The fields on the property tab for datatypes are described in Table 14.6. Property fields for datatype.

Table 14.6. Property fields for datatype

FieldMeaning
Name

Text box. The name of the datatype. The primitive datatypes all have lower case names, but there is no formal convention.

Note

The default name supplied to a new package by ArgoUML is the empty string “”. The datatype will appear with the name anon in the navigation pane.

Stereotype

Drop down selector. Package is provided by default with the UML standard stereotypes for classifier (metaclass, powertype, process, thread and utility). ArgoUML also provides the additional stereotypes, machine, organization and person as well as the abstraction stereotype realize.

Most important of all, ArgoUML provides the stereotype enumeration for use with user defined enumeration data types.

Tip

enumeration should always be used as the stereotype of any created datatypes.

Caution

Use of other stereotypes (particularly realize is unwise. If you really need to stereotype user defined types, you should consider creating your own stereotype derived from enumeration.

Navigate Stereotype

icon. If a stereotype has been selected, this will navigate you to the stereotype property panel (see Section 14.4).

Extends

Text box. Lists any use case extended by this datatype. Meaningless for a datatype. The entry is always none and the pop up menu grayed out.

Implements

Text box. Lists any abstract classes or interfaces realized by this datatype. By default shows the entry none.

Button 1 click takes you to any entry (but see the warning below), button 2 gives a pop up menu with five entries.

  • Open. Where an abstraction dependency exists, navigate to it (but see warning below).

  • Add. Add a new abstraction dependency.

    Note

    ArgoUML does not navigate to the new abstraction, and this field shows the name [empty], whatever name you choose to give the abstraction.

    Tip

    Whilst adding abstractions is possible, only the supplier end is created, and there is no way to supply the client end. The value of such abstractions is therefore minimal.

  • Delete. Where an abstraction has been added this removes it completely from the model.

  • Move Up. Only available where there are two or more abstractions, and the abstraction selected is not at the top. It is moved one up the list.

  • Move Down. Only available where there are two or more abstractions listed, and the abstraction selected is not at the bottom. It is moved one down the list.

Tip

In principle a datatype could realize some other artifact, but it would be unusual. Best avoided.

Warning

Button 1 click on the default entry navigates to the most recently selected to-do item in the to-do pane. This seems to be a bug in ArgoUML.

Modifiers

Check box, with entries public, abstract, final and root.

  • public has identical meaning to the public declaration in Java. It indicates whether this datatype is restricted to use in its own package (the default) or can be used by anyone.

  • abstract is used to declare that this datatype cannot be instantiated, but must always be specialized.

    Caution

    ArgoUML provides no mechanism for specializing datatypes, so this check box is of little use.

  • final indicates that this datatype can have no further sub-types, while root indicates it is a top level datatype.

    Tip

    In the absence of specialization of datatypes within ArgoUML these have little value. In effect all datatypes are both root and final

Namespace

Text box. Records the namespace for the datatype. This is the package hierarchy.

Button 1 click on the entry will take you to the package defining this namespace (or the model for the top level namespace).

Derived

Text box. Meaningless for a datatype (which can never be a generalization), which always shows the entry none here. The pop-up menu is always grayed out.

Operations

Text area. Lists all the operations defined on this datatype. Button 1 click takes you to the selected operation, button 2 click brings up a pop up menu with five entries.

  • Open. Navigate to the selected operation.

  • Add. Add a new operation and navigate to it.

  • Delete. Removes the selected operation from the model.

  • Move Up. Only available where there are two or more operations, and the operation selected is not at the top. It is moved one up the list.

  • Move Down. Only available where there are two or more operations listed, and the operation selected is not at the bottom. It is moved one down the list.

See Section 16.7 for details of operations.

Caution

ArgoUML treats all operations as equivalent. Any operations created here will use the same mechanism as operations for classes. Remember that operations on datatypes must have no side effects (they are read-only). This means the query modifier must be checked for all operations.

Literals

Text area. Lists all the literals defined for this datatype. Button 1 click takes you to the selected literal, button 2 click brings up a pop up menu with five entries.

  • Open. Navigate to the selected literal.

  • Add. Add a new literal and navigate to it.

  • Delete. Removes the selected literal from the model.

  • Move Up. Only available where there are two or more literals, and the literal selected is not at the top. It is moved one up the list.

  • Move Down. Only available where there are two or more literals listed, and the literal selected is not at the bottom. It is moved one down the list.

Caution

ArgoUML does not actually have a separate concept of a literal. The navigations listed above will all take you to the property sheet for an attribute of a class (see Section 16.6). When defining a literal, all that matters is its name. Other parts of the attribute property sheet should be ignored.

14.4. Stereotypes

Stereotypes are the main extension mechanism of UML, providing a way to derive specializations of the standard metaclasses. Stereotype is a sub-class of GeneralizableElement in the UML metamodel. Stereotypes are supplemented by constraints and tagged values.

New stereotypes are added from the model property tab (see Section 14.2, the package property tab (see Section 16.2) or the stereotype property tab itself (see below). Properties of existing stereotypes can be reached by selecting the property tab for any artifact with that stereotype and using the navstereo button () within the property tab.

Note

Due to a bug in ArgoUML newly created stereotypes do not appear in stereotype drop down menus. Where the stereotypes apply to a class, it is sufficient to select a new class and then select the original class back. However this does not work for other artifacts. The solution is to save and reload the model.

14.4.1. Stereotype Details Tabs

The details tabs that are active for stereotypes are described in Table 14.7. Details tabs for stereotype.

Note

The Style tab is grayed out, since a stereotype has no representation on a diagram.

Table 14.7. Details tabs for stereotype

TabMeaning
ToDoItem

Standard tab.

Properties

See Table 14.8. Property tool bar for stereotype and Table 14.9. Property fields for stereotype below.

Documentation

Standard tab.

Source

Standard tab. This contains the representation of the stereotype on diagrams (its name between « and »).

Warning

You can edit this entry, but it has no effect and when you return to the entry it will be restored to its original value.

Constraints

Standard tab. There are no standard constraints defined for Package within the UML metamodel.

Caution

Constraints for a stereotype are rather different to those for elements in the UML core architecture, in that they apply to all artifacts to which the stereotype is applied, not just the stereotype itself.

Tagged Values

Standard tab. In the UML metamodel, Stereotype has the following standard tagged values defined.

  • derived (from the superclass, ModelElement). Values true, meaning the class is redundant—it can be formally derived from other elements, or false meaning it cannot.

    Note

    This indicates any element with this stereotype has the derived tag set accordingly.

Note

The UML Element metaclass from which all other artifacts are derived includes the tagged element documentation which is handled by the documentation tab under ArgoUML

Caution

Tagged values for a stereotype are rather different to those for elements in the UML core architecture, in that they apply to all artifacts to which the stereotype is applied, not just the stereotype itself.

14.4.2. Stereotype Properties

The property tab tool bar for stereotypes is described in Table 14.8. Property tool bar for stereotype.

Table 14.8. Property tool bar for stereotype

ButtonIconMeaning
Go up

Navigate up through the package structure of the model.

Go back

Navigate back to the previous artifact.

Warning

This feature is currently broken within ArgoUML and there is no guarantee where (if anywhere) this button will take you.

Go forward

Navigate forward to the next artifact.

Warning

This feature is currently broken within ArgoUML and there is no guarantee where (if anywhere) this button will take you.

Add stereotype

This creates a new stereotype (see Section 14.4) within the model (which appears on no diagram), navigating immediately to the properties tab for that stereotype.

Delete

This deletes the stereotype from the model.

The fields on the property tab for stereotypes are described in Table 14.9. Property fields for stereotype.

Table 14.9. Property fields for stereotype

FieldMeaning
Name

Text box. The name of the stereotype. There is no convention for naming stereotypes, beyond starting them with a lower case letter. Even the standard UML stereotypes vary between all lower case (e.g. metamodel), bumpy caps (e.g. systemModel) and space separated (e.g. object model).

Note

ArgoUML does not enforce any naming convention for stereotypes

Base Class

Drop down selector. Any stereotype must be derived from one of the metaclasses in the UML metamodel Abstraction, Association, AssociationEnd, BehavioralFeature, CallEvent, Class, Classifier, Collaboration, Comment, Component, Constraint, DataType, Dependency, Flow, Generalization, Model, ModelElement, ObjectFlowState, Package, Permission, Subsystem and Usage) or the artifact classes that derive from them. The stereotype will then be available to artifacts that derive from that same metaclass or that artifact.

Namespace

Text box. Records the namespace for the stereotype. This is the package hierarchy.

Button 1 click on the entry will take you to the package defining this namespace (or the model for the top level namespace).

Extends

Text box. Lists any use case that is extended by this stereotype. Meaningless for a stereotype.

Modifiers

Check box, with entries Abstract, Final and Root.

  • abstract is used to declare that artifacts that use this stereotype cannot be instantiated, but must always be specialized.

  • final indicates that artifacts that use this stereotype can have no further sub-types, while root indicates it is a top level artifact.

Caution

Remember that these modifiers apply to the artifacts using the stereotype, not just the stereotype.

Warning

ArgoUML does neither imposes, nor checks that artifacts using a stereotype adopt the stereotype's modifiers.

Derived

Text box. Lists any derived stereotype. The drop down menu Open is permanently grayed out, suggesting it may not be possible to create derived stereotypes within ArgoUML.

14.5. ArgoUML Diagrams

ArgoUML supports seven types of diagrams: i) use case; ii) class; iii) sequence; iv) state; v) collaboration; vi) activity; and vii) deployment. They are created using the Create Diagram drop down menu (see Section 12.6).

Note

State and activity diagrams are associated with a particular class, and can only be created when a class has been selected. In the current version of ArgoUML they are not grayed out even when a class is not selected. However under these circumstances they will have no effect.

14.5.1. Diagram Details Tabs

The details tabs that are active for diagrams are described in Table 14.10. Details tabs for diagram.

Table 14.10. Details tabs for diagram

TabMeaning
ToDoItem

Standard tab.

Properties

See Table 14.11. Property tool bar for diagram and Table 14.12. Property fields for diagram below.

Source

Holds a reference to the ArgoUML implementation class for that diagram.

Note

The source tab content can be changed, but this has no effect.

14.5.2. Diagram Properties

The property tab tool bar for diagrams is described in Table 14.11. Property tool bar for diagram.

Table 14.11. Property tool bar for diagram

ButtonIconMeaning
Go back

Navigate back to the previous diagram. Always grayed out, since there is no way to navigate to a diagram (and hence no way to navigate back).

Go forward

Navigate forward to the next diagram. Always grayed out, since there is no way to navigate to a diagram (and hence no way to navigate forward).

The fields on the property tab for diagrams are described in Table 14.12. Property fields for diagram.

Table 14.12. Property fields for diagram

FieldMeaning
Name

The name of the diagram. There are no conventions for naming diagrams. By default, ArgoUML uses the (space separated) diagram name and a sequence number, thus use case diagram 1.

Chapter 15. ArgoUML Use Case Diagram Artifact Reference

Table of Contents

15.1 Introduction
15.1.1 ArgoUML Limitations Concerning Use Case Diagrams
15.2 Actor
15.2.1 Actor Details Tabs
15.2.2 Actor Properties
15.3 Use Case
15.3.1 Use Case Details Tabs
15.3.2 Use Case Properties
15.4 Association
15.4.1 Association Details Tabs
15.4.2 Association Properties
15.5 Association End
15.5.1 Association End Details Tabs
15.5.2 Association End Properties
15.6 Generalization
15.6.1 Generalization Details Tabs
15.6.2 Generalization Properties
15.7 Dependency
15.7.1 Dependency Details Tabs
15.7.2 Dependency Properties

15.1. Introduction

This chapter describes each artifact that can be created within a use case diagram. Note that some sub-artifacts of artifacts on the diagram may not actually themselves appear on the diagram.

There is a close relationship between this material and the properties tab of the details pane (see Section 10.4). That section covers properties in general, in this chapter they are linked to specific artifacts.

Figure 15.1. Possible artifacts on a use case diagram. shows a use case diagram with all possible artifacts displayed.

Figure 15.1. Possible artifacts on a use case diagram.

15.1.1. ArgoUML Limitations Concerning Use Case Diagrams

During the standardization process of UML, there was considerable change over the definition of Includes (originally known as Uses) and Extends. Initially they were specializations of Generalization within the UML metamodel (itself a specialization of Relationship.

In UML 1.3, Includes and Extends are defined as specializations directly from Relationship.

Warning

ArgoUML further confuses matters by defining Includes and Extends as stereotyped specializations of Dependency (itself a specialization of Relationship. This is an area where ArgoUML is out of line at present with the standard.

Further difficulties arise with Extension Points, the points within a use case, where extending use cases may be invoked. In the absence of a LocationReference within ArgoUML these are restricted to purely documentation features.

15.2. Actor

An actor represents any external entity (human or machine) that interacts with the system, providing input, receiving output, or both.

Within the UML metamodel, actor is a sub-class of classifier.

The actor icon is a stick man (see Figure 15.1. Possible artifacts on a use case diagram.).

15.2.1. Actor Details Tabs

The details tabs that are active for actors are described in Table 15.1. Details tabs for actor.

Table 15.1. Details tabs for actor

TabMeaning
ToDoItem

Standard tab.

Properties

See Table 15.2. Property tool bar for diagram and Table 15.3. Property fields for actor below.

Documentation

Standard tab.

Style

Standard tab. Fill color is used for the stick man's head.

Source

Standard tab. It would not be usual to provide any code for an actor, since it is external to the system.

Note

The source tab content can be changed, but this has no effect.

Constraints

Standard tab. There are no standard constraints defined for Actor within the UML metamodel.

Tagged Values

Standard tab. In the UML metamodel, Actor has the following standard tagged values defined.

  • persistence (from the superclass, Classifier). Values transitory, indicating state is destroyed when an instance is destroyed or persistent, marking state is preserved when an instance is destroyed.

    Tip

    Actors sit outside the system, and so their internal behavior is of little concern, and this tagged value is best ignored.

  • semantics (from the superclass, Classifier). The value is a specification of the semantics of the actor.

  • derived (from the superclass, ModelElement). Values true, meaning the actor is redundant—it can be formally derived from other elements, or false meaning it cannot.

    Note

    Derived actors have limited value, since they sit outside the system being designed. They may have their value in analysis to introduce useful names or concepts.

Note

The UML Element metaclass from which all other artifacts are derived includes the tagged element documentation which is handled by the documentation tab under ArgoUML

15.2.2. Actor Properties

The property tab tool bar for actors is described in Table 15.2. Property tool bar for diagram.

Table 15.2. Property tool bar for diagram

ButtonIconMeaning
Go up

Navigate up through the package structure of the model.

Go back

Navigate back to the previous artifact.

Warning

This feature is currently broken within ArgoUML and there is no guarantee where (if anywhere) this button will take you.

Go forward

Navigate forward to the next artifact.

Warning

This feature is currently broken within ArgoUML and there is no guarantee where (if anywhere) this button will take you.

New actor

This creates a new actor within the model, (but not within the diagram), navigating immediately to the properties tab for that actor.

Tip

This method of creating new actors can be confusing. Much better to create them within diagrams where you want them.

Delete

This deletes the selected actor from the model.

Warning

This is a deletion from the model not just the diagram. To delete an actor from the diagram, but keep it within the model, use the main menu Edit/Remove From Diagram (Ctrl-R).

The fields on the property tab for actors are described in Table 15.3. Property fields for actor.

Table 15.3. Property fields for actor

FieldMeaning
Name

Text box. The name of the actor. Since an actor is a classifier, it would be conventional to Capitalize the first letter (and initial letters of any component words), e.g. RemoteSensor.

Note

ArgoUML does not enforce any naming convention for actors

Stereotype

Drop down selector. Actor is provided by default with the UML standard stereotypes (metaclass, powertype, process, thread, utility) for classifiers. ArgoUML also provides the additional stereotypes, machine, organization and person. Stereotypes are of limited value with actors, but these last three are probably of most use.

Navigate Stereotype

icon. If a stereotype has been selected, this will navigate you to the stereotype property panel (see Section 14.4).

Namespace

Text box. Records the namespace for the actor. This is the package hierarchy.

Button 1 click on the entry will take you to the package defining this namespace (or the model for the top level namespace).

Modifiers

Check box, with entries Abstract, Final and Root.

  • abstract is used to declare that this actor cannot be instantiated, but must always be specialized.

    Caution

    Whilst actors can be specialized and generalized, it is not clear that an abstract actor has any meaning. Perhaps it might be used to indicate an actor that does not itself interact with a use case, but whose children do.

  • final indicates that this actor can have no further children, while root indicates it is a top level actor with no parent.

Derived

Text box. Lists any derived actor (i.e. for which this actor is a generalization. The derived actors can communicate with the same use case instances as this actor.

button 1 click navigates to the generalization and opens its property tab.

Button 2 click yields a drop down menu, with a single entry, Openwhich navigates to the generalization and opens its property tab.

Warning

An actor may generalize several other actors. Although they will all appear in the Derived text box, the absence of a comprehensive drop down menu (Open, Add, Delete, Move Up and Move Down) renders access to all but the first impossible via this field. They can of course be accessed through the navigation pane or diagram.

Extends

Text area. Lists any use case that generalizes this actor.

Button 1 click navigates to the generalization and opens its property tab.

Button 2 click yields a drop down menu with five entries

  • Open. Navigate to the selected generalization.

  • Add. Add a new generalization. Note that the new generalization is added to the model, but not the diagram. You will need to find it in the navigation pane and add it from there.

    Tip

    It is far easier to add generalizations by drawing them on the relevant diagram in the editing pane.

  • Delete. The link from the generalization to the actor (but not the generalization itself) is removed.

    Tip

    This does not remove the generalization from the model or the diagram, leading to potentially very confusing diagrams. It is usually far easier to remove generalizations from the editing pane.

  • Move Up. Only available where there are two or more generalizations listed, and the generalization selected is not at the top. It is moved one up the list.

  • Move Down. Only available where there are two or more generalizations listed, and the generalization selected is not at the bottom. It is moved one down the list.

Warning

The use of the term Extends by ArgoUML is misleading, since this field does not relate to extends relationships, but to generalization relationships.

Associations

Text area. Lists any associations connected to the actor. Button 1 click on an association will navigate to that association. Button 2 click gives a pop up menu with five options.

  • Open. Where a navigation exists, navigate to it.

  • Add. Add a new association. Note that the new association is added to the model, but not the diagram. You will need to find it in the navigation pane and add it from there.

    Tip

    It is far easier to add associations by drawing them on the relevant diagram in the editing pane.

  • Delete. Where an association is linked to this actor, this removes the link to the actor.

    Tip

    This does not remove the association from the model or the diagram, leading to potentially very confusing diagrams. It is usually far easier to remove associations from the editing pane.

  • Move Up. Only available where there are two or more associations listed, and the association selected is not at the top. It is moved one up the list.

  • Move Down. Only available where there are two or more associations listed, and the association selected is not at the bottom. It is moved one down the list.

Implements

Text area. Listing the classes that are implemented by this actor. Although it is possible to create an abstraction through a button 2 pop up menu, this makes no sense for an actor.

15.3. Use Case

A use case represents a complete meaningful “chunk” of activity by the system in relation to its external users (actors), human or machine. It represents the primary route through which requirements are captured for the system under construction

Within the UML metamodel, use case is a sub-class of classifier.

The use case icon is an oval (see Figure 15.1. Possible artifacts on a use case diagram.).

15.3.1. Use Case Details Tabs

The details tabs that are active for use cases are described in Table 15.4. Details tabs for use case.

Table 15.4. Details tabs for use case

TabMeaning
ToDoItem

Standard tab.

Properties

See Table 15.5. Property tool bar for diagram and Table 15.6. Property fields for use case below.

Documentation

Standard tab.

Style

Standard tab. Fill color is used for the use case oval.

Source

Standard tab. It would not be usual to provide any code for a use case, since it is primarily a vehicle for capturing requirements about the system under construction, not creating the solution.

Constraints

Standard tab. There are no standard constraints defined for UseCase within the UML metamodel.

Tagged Values

Standard tab. In the UML metamodel, UseCase has the following standard tagged values defined.

  • persistence (from the superclass, Classifier). Values transitory, indicating state is destroyed when an instance is destroyed or persistent, marking state is preserved when an instance is destroyed.

    Tip

    In general the instantiation of use cases is not a major aspect of any design method (they are mostly concerned with requirements capture. For most OOA&D methodologies, this tag can safely be ignored.

  • semantics (from the superclass, Classifier). The value is a specification of the semantics of the use case.

  • derived (from the superclass, ModelElement). Values true, meaning the use case is redundant—it can be formally derived from other elements, or false meaning it cannot.

    Note

    Derived use cases still have their value in analysis to introduce useful names or concepts.

Note

The UML Element metaclass from which all other artifacts are derived includes the tagged element documentation which is handled by the documentation tab under ArgoUML

15.3.2. Use Case Properties

The property tab tool bar for use cases is described in Table 15.5. Property tool bar for diagram.

Table 15.5. Property tool bar for diagram

ButtonIconMeaning
Go up

Navigate up through the package structure of the model.

Go back

Navigate back to the previous artifact.

Warning

This feature is currently broken within ArgoUML and there is no guarantee where (if anywhere) this button will take you.

Go forward

Navigate forward to the next artifact.

Warning

This feature is currently broken within ArgoUML and there is no guarantee where (if anywhere) this button will take you.

New use case

This creates a new use case within the model, (but not within the diagram), navigating immediately to the properties tab for that use case.

Tip

This method of creating new use cases can be confusing. Much better to create them within diagrams where you want them.

Delete

This deletes the selected use case from the model.

Warning

This is a deletion from the model not just the diagram. To delete a use case from the diagram, but keep it within the model, use the main menu Edit/Remove From Diagram (Ctrl-R).

The fields on the property tab for use cases are described in Table 15.6. Property fields for use case.

Table 15.6. Property fields for use case

FieldMeaning
Name

Text box. The name of the use case. Since a use case is a classifier, it would be conventional to Capitalize the first letter (and initial letters of any component words), e.g. RemoteSensor.

Note

ArgoUML does not enforce any naming convention for use cases

Stereotype

Drop down selector. Use case is provided by default with the UML standard stereotypes (metaclass, powertype, process, thread, utility) for classifiers. ArgoUML also provides the additional stereotypes, machine, organization and person. Stereotyping can be useful when creating use cases in the problem domain (requirements capture) and solution domain (analysis), but none of the pre-defined stereotypes are well suited to this.

Warning

If a stereotype is selected in ArgoUML it will not be displayed in the diagram.

Navigate Stereotype

icon. If a stereotype has been selected, this will navigate you to the stereotype property panel (see Section 14.4).

Namespace

Text box. Records the namespace for the use case. This is the package hierarchy.

Button 1 click on the entry will take you to the package defining this namespace (or the model for the top level namespace).

Modifiers

Check box, with entries Abstract, Final and Root.

  • abstract is used to declare that this use case cannot be instantiated, but must always be specialized.

    Caution

    Whilst use cases can be specialized and generalized, it is not clear that an abstract use case has any meaning. Perhaps it might be used to indicate an use case that does not itself interact with an actor, but whose children do.

  • final indicates that this use case can have no further children, while root indicates it is a top level use case with no parent.

Generalizations

Text area. Lists use cases which are generalizations of this one. Will be set whenever a generalization is created on the diagram. Button 1 click on a generalization will navigate to that generalization. Button 2 click gives a pop up menu with five options.

  • Open. Where a generalization exists, navigate to it.

  • Add. Add a new generalization. Note that the new association is added to the model, but not the diagram. You will need to find it in the navigation pane and add it from there.

    Tip

    It is far easier to add generalizations by drawing them on the relevant diagram in the editing pane.

    Caution

    It is possible to add multiple generalizations. However is is hard to see a sensible meaning for this. In addition the size of the text area makes this very inconvenient in ArgoUML.

  • Delete. Where a generalization exists linking to this use case, this removes the link to this use case.

    Tip

    This does not remove the generalization from the model or the diagram, leading to potentially very confusing diagrams. It is usually far easier to remove generalizations from the editing pane.

  • Move Up. Only available where there are two or more generalizations listed (see caution above), and the generalization selected is not at the top. It is moved one up the list.

  • Move Down. Only available where there are two or more generalizations listed (see caution above), and the generalization selected is not at the bottom. It is moved one down the list.

Extends

Text box. Lists any class that is extended by this use case. In ArgoUML at present extension on a use case diagram is through stereotyping a dependency relationship, which will not show in this box.

Where an extends relationship has been created (see below), button 1 click will navigate to that relationship. Button 2 gives a pop up menu through which an anonymous extends relationship can be created.

  • Open. Where an extends relationship has been created, navigate to it.

  • Add. Add a new anonymous extends relationship. This is just a documentation artifact, not a true relationship, where you can record details of the extension.

    Caution

    It is possible to add multiple extends relationships. However is is hard to see a sensible meaning for this. In addition the size of the text area, and the lack of move up/move down options on the pop up menu, make all but the top entry inaccessible in ArgoUML.

  • Delete. Where an extends relationship has been created through use of Add pop up menu, this removes it.

Includes

Text box. Lists any class that this use case includes. In ArgoUML at present inclusion on a use case diagram is through stereotyping a dependency relationship, which will not show in this box.

Where an includes relationship has been created (see below), button 1 click will navigate to that relationship. Button 2 gives a pop up menu through which an anonymous includes relationship can be created.

  • Open. Where an includes relationship has been created, navigate to it.

  • Add. Add a new anonymous includes relationship. This is just a documentation artifact, not a true relationship, where you can record details of the extension.

    Caution

    It is possible to add multiple includes relationships. However is is hard to see a sensible meaning for this. In addition the size of the text area, and the lack of move up/move down options on the pop up menu, make all but the top entry inaccessible in ArgoUML.

  • Delete. Where an includes relationship has been created through use of Add pop up menu, this removes it.

Extension Points

Text box. If this use case is, or can be extended, this field is used to document the points at which such extensions can occur.

Where an extension point has been created (see below), button 1 click will navigate to that relationship. Button 2 gives a pop up menu through which an anonymous extension points can be created.

  • Open. Where an extension point has been created, navigate to it.

  • Add. Add a new anonymous extension point. This is a documentation artifact, where you can record details of the extension point.

    Note

    At present there is no way to give a name to an extension point in ArgoUML.

  • Delete. Where an extension point has been created through use of Add pop up menu, this removes it.

Associations

Text area. Lists any associations connected to the use case. Button 1 click on an association will navigate to that association. Button 2 click gives a pop up menu with five options.

  • Open. Navigate to the association.

  • Add. Add a new association. Note that the new association is added to the model, but not the diagram. You will need to find it in the navigation pane and add it from there.

    Tip

    It is far easier to add associations by drawing them on the relevant diagram in the editing pane.

  • Delete. Where an association is linked to a use case, this removes the link to the use case.

    Tip

    This does not remove the association from the model or the diagram, leading to potentially very confusing diagrams. It is usually far easier to remove associations from the editing pane.

  • Move Up. Only available where there are two or more associations listed, and the association selected is not at the top. It is moved one up the list.

  • Move Down. Only available where there are two or more associations listed, and the association selected is not at the bottom. It is moved one down the list.

Operations

Text area. Listing the operations that are available on this use case. As a sub-class of the UML classifier metaclass, a use case has many of the properties of a class (see Section 16.5).

In some OOA&D processes it might be useful to treat use cases as classes as well, and give them operations and attributes. This is of very limited in ArgoUML, since it is not possible to take a use case and add it to a class diagram, so all class relationships must be shown with the notation of a use case diagram.

Should you wish to add operations to a use case, button 1 click allows you to navigate to them and button 2 click gives a pop up menu with options to Open, Add, Delete, Move Up and Move Down (see Generalizations for examples of how these operations are used).

Attributes

Text area. Listing the attributes that are available on this use case. As a sub-class of the UML classifier metaclass, a use case has many of the properties of a class (see Section 16.5).

In some OOA&D processes it might be useful to treat use cases as classes as well, and give them operations and attributes. This is of very limited in ArgoUML, since it is not possible to take a use case and add it to a class diagram, so all class relationships must be shown with the notation of a use case diagram.

Should you wish to add attributes to a use case, button 1 click allows you to navigate to them and button 2 click gives a pop up menu with options to Open, Add, Delete, Move Up and Move Down (see Generalizations for examples of how these operations are used).

15.4. Association

An association on a use case diagram represents is a relationship between an actor and a use case showing that actor's involvement in the use case. The invocation of the use case will involve some (significant) change perceived by the actor.

Within the UML metamodel, Association is a sub-class of both Relationship and GeneralizableElement.

The association is represented as a line connecting actor and use case (see Figure 15.1. Possible artifacts on a use case diagram.). The name of the association appears above the line and any stereotype above that.

Note

ArgoUML provides no specific way of showing the direction of the association as described in the UML 1.3 standard. The naming should attempt to make this clear.

The association contains two ends, which may be navigated to via the association property sheet. See Section 15.5 for more information.

15.4.1. Association Details Tabs

The details tabs that are active for associations are described in Table 15.7. Details tabs for association.

Table 15.7. Details tabs for association

TabMeaning
ToDoItem

Standard tab.

Properties

See Table 15.8. Property tool bar for diagram and Table 15.9. Property fields for association below.

Documentation

Standard tab.

Style

Standard tab. Fill color is used for the use case oval.

Note

The values for the bounds of the Association appear to have no meaning. Changing them has no effect on the diagram. This is sensible behavior, given the association is tied to a particular actor and use case.

Source

Standard tab. You would not expect to generate any code for an association, and any code entered here is ignored (it will have disappeared when you come back to the association.

Constraints

Standard tab. In the UML metamodel, Association has the following standard constraints defined.

  • xor. Applied to a set of associations, indicating that over that set, exactly one association is manifest for any particular association instance.

Tagged Values

Standard tab. In the UML metamodel, Association has the following standard tagged values defined.

  • persistence. Values transitory, indicating state is destroyed when an instance is destroyed or persistent, marking state is preserved when an instance is destroyed.

  • derived (from the superclass, ModelElement). Values true, meaning the association is redundant—it can be formally derived from other elements, or false meaning it cannot.

    Note

    Derived associations still have their value in analysis to introduce useful names or concepts, and in design to avoid re-computation.

Note

The UML Element metaclass from which all other artifacts are derived includes the tagged element documentation which is handled by the documentation tab under ArgoUML

15.4.2. Association Properties

The property tab tool bar for associations is described in Table 15.8. Property tool bar for diagram.

Table 15.8. Property tool bar for diagram

ButtonIconMeaning
Go up

Navigate up through the package structure of the model. For an association this will be the package containing the association.

Go back

Navigate back to the previous artifact.

Warning

This feature is currently broken within ArgoUML and there is no guarantee where (if anywhere) this button will take you.

Go forward

Navigate forward to the next artifact.

Warning

This feature is currently broken within ArgoUML and there is no guarantee where (if anywhere) this button will take you.

Delete

This deletes the selected association from the model.

Warning

This is a deletion from the model not just the diagram. To delete an association from the diagram, but keep it within the model, use the main menu Edit/Remove From Diagram (Ctrl-R).

The fields on the property tab for associations are described in Table 15.9. Property fields for association.

Table 15.9. Property fields for association

FieldMeaning
Name

Text box. The name of the association. By convention association names start with a lower case letter, with “bumpy caps” used to indicate words within the name, thus: salesHandling.

Note

ArgoUML does not enforce any naming convention for associations.

Tip

Although the design critics will advise otherwise, it is perfectly normal not to name associations on a use case, since the relationship is obvious from the actor and use case name.

Stereotype

Drop down selector. Association is provided by default with the UML standard stereotype for Association ((implicit)) and the additional Association stereotypes for the Software Engineering Process and Business Modeling in the UML standard (communicate and subscribe). ArgoUML also provides the additional stereotypes, machine, organization and person and four additional stereotypes suggested by some writers using patterns (offstage actor, primary actor, stakeholder and supporting actor).

Stereotyping can be useful when creating use cases in the problem domain (requirements capture) and solution domain (analysis), as well as for processes based on patterns.

The stereotype is shown between « and » above the name of the association on the diagram.

Warning

The provision of offstage actor, primary actor, stakeholder and supporting actor by ArgoUML as stereotypes of Association appears to be erroneous. They should be stereotypes of Actor (or arguably Classifier).

Navigate Stereotype

icon. If a stereotype has been selected, this will navigate you to the stereotype property panel (see Section 14.4).

Namespace

Text box. Records the namespace for the association. This is the package hierarchy.

Button 1 click on the entry will take you to the package defining this namespace (or the model for the top level namespace).

Modifiers

Check box, with entries Abstract, Final and Root. No known use.

Tip

Whilst attributes are generalizable elements, marking them as with these modifiers is of limited value with binary associations (the only support that ArgoUML supports properly.

Association Ends

Text area. Lists the ends of this association. An association can have any number of ends, but for use cases, two is the only useful number (associative classes can led to a third end on class diagrams, but this is not supported by ArgoUML). For more on association ends see Section 15.5.

The names are listed, unless the association end has no name (the case when it is first created), in which case the artifact at that end, and its multiplicity, is shown.

Note

The only representation of association ends on a diagram is that their name appears at the relevant end of the corresponding association. There is no way to access them from the diagram.

Button 1 click on an association end will navigate to that end. Button 2 click gives a pop up menu with five options.

  • Open. Where an association end exists, navigate to it.

  • Add. Add a new association end and navigate to its property tab.

    Tip

    Whilst adding new ends is possible, the value of this is limited for Use Case diagrams where the standard two ends is all that is every needed.

  • Delete. Where an association end this removes it completely from the model.

  • Move Up. Only available where there are two or more association ends, and the association end selected is not at the top. It is moved one up the list.

  • Move Down. Only available where there are two or more association ends listed, and the association end selected is not at the bottom. It is moved one down the list.

Extends

Text box. These are the associations for which this association is a specialization. It is possible to create generalizations using the pop-up menu from here, but there is no way within ArgoUML to give them a parent, so the entry has no use

Caution

This entry should properly be called Generalizations.

Derived

Text box. These are the associations for which this association is a generalization. The drop down menu is always grayed out.

Caution

This entry should properly be called Specializations.

15.5. Association End

Two or more association ends are associated with each association (see Section 15.4), although for the purposes of use case diagrams, the number of ends can only usefully be two.

Within the UML metamodel, AssociationEnd is a sub-class of ModelElement.

The association end has no direct representation on any diagram, although its name is shown at the relevant end of the parent association (see Figure 15.1. Possible artifacts on a use case diagram.).

Tip

Although you can change attributes of association ends when creating a use case model, this is often not necessary. Many of the properties of an association end relate to its use in class diagrams, and are of limited relevance to use cases. The most useful attributes to consider altering are the name (used as the role name) and the multiplicity.

Note

ArgoUML does not currently support qualifiers, as described in the UML 1.3 standard.

15.5.1. Association End Details Tabs

The details tabs that are active for associations are described in Table 15.10. Details tabs for association end.

Table 15.10. Details tabs for association end

TabMeaning
ToDoItem

Standard tab.

Properties

See Table 15.11. Property tool bar for diagram and Table 15.12. Property fields for association end below.

Documentation

Standard tab.

Style

Standard tab, but with no meaning, since the only representation is via the parent association.

Source

Standard tab. You would not expect to generate any code for an association end, but this tab contains a declaration for the association end as an instance of the actor or use case artifact to which it is connected.

Note

This is probably not the correct thing to do for good code generation, and will need to be changed in future versions of ArgoUML.

Constraints

Standard tab. There are no standard constraints defined for AssociationEnd within the UML metamodel.

Tagged Values

Standard tab. In the UML metamodel, AssociationEnd has the following standard tagged values defined.

  • derived (from the superclass, ModelElement). Values true, meaning the association end is redundant—it can be formally derived from other elements, or false meaning it cannot.

    Tip

    Derived association ends still have their value in analysis to introduce useful names or concepts, and in design to avoid re-computation. However they their composition with association, means they can only sensibly have a true derived tag if the association also does.

Note

The UML Element metaclass from which all other artifacts are derived includes the tagged element documentation which is handled by the documentation tab under ArgoUML

15.5.2. Association End Properties

The property tab tool bar for associations is described in Table 15.11. Property tool bar for diagram.

Table 15.11. Property tool bar for diagram

ButtonIconMeaning
Go up

Navigate up to the association to which this end belongs.

Go back

Navigate back to the previous artifact.

Warning

This feature is currently broken within ArgoUML and there is no guarantee where (if anywhere) this button will take you.

Go forward

Navigate forward to the next artifact.

Warning

This feature is currently broken within ArgoUML and there is no guarantee where (if anywhere) this button will take you.

Go to other end

This navigates to the other end of the association.

The fields on the property tab for association ends are described in Table 15.12. Property fields for association end.

Table 15.12. Property fields for association end

FieldMeaning
Name

Text box. The name of the association end, which provides a role name for this end of the association. This role name can be used for navigation, and in an implementation context (not really relevant to use case diagrams), provides a name by which the source end of an association can reference the target end.

Note

ArgoUML does not enforce any naming convention for associations.

Stereotype

Drop down selector. Association end is provided by default with the UML standard stereotypes for AssociationEnd (association, global, local, parameter, self). ArgoUML also provides the additional stereotypes, machine, organization and person.

Stereotyping association ends can be very useful in class diagrams. However it is of limited use in use case diagrams, although the default stereotype of association can be used to emphasis this.

Warning

There is no diagram representation of the stereotype of an association end.

Navigate Stereotype

icon. If a stereotype has been selected, this will navigate you to the stereotype property panel (see Section 14.4).

Type

Drop down selector providing access to all standard UML types provided by ArgoUML and all new classes created within the current model.

This is the type of the entity attached to this end of the association.

Tip

By default ArgoUML will select the class of the artifact to which the linkend is connected. There is little point in altering this when working with use case diagrams.

Caution

When you create new classes elsewhere in ArgoUML they will not appear in this drop down until after the model has been saved and reloaded.

Navigate Class

icon. If a datatype, interface or class has been selected, this will navigate you to its property sheet, (see Section 14.3, Section 16.14 and Section 16.5) .

Multiplicity

Drop down menu. Records the multiplicity of this association end (with respect to the other end), i.e. how many instances of this end may be associated with an instance of the other end.

Tip

For use case diagrams you can often ignore this, at least in the early stages.

Association

Text box. Records the parent association for this association end. Button 1 click on this entry will take you to that association. Button 2 click will invoke a pop-up menu, with a single entry, Open that will also navigate you to that association.

Navigable

Check box, with a single entry, navigable. Indicates that this end can be navigated to from the other end.

Tip

This means little to a use case diagram. It is useful for associations on class diagrams.

Note

The UML 1.3 standard provides a number of options for how navigation is displayed on an association end. ArgoUML uses option 3, which means that arrow heads are shown at the end of an association, when navigation is enabled at only one end, to indicate the direction in which navigation is possible. This means that the default, with both ends navigable has non arrows. This is an appropriate representation for use cases.

Ordering

Radio box, with three entries unordered, ordered and sorted. Where there are multiple instances indicates the nature of any ordering.

Note

sorted represents an extension to UML 1.3.

Tip

This means little to a use case diagram. It is useful for associations on class diagrams.

Aggregation

Radio box, with three entries none, aggregation and composite. Indicates whether the relationship with the far end represents some type of loose grouping (aggregation) or tight grouping (composite.

Note

You may not have aggregation at both ends of an association.

Tip

Whilst it does have some meaning, it is of limited use to show aggregation on a use case diagram. It is useful for associations on class diagrams.

Classifier

Check box, with a single entry, classifier. Indicates that this end relates to a class rather than an instance of a class (the default).

Tip

Not relevant to a use case diagram. It is useful for associations on class diagrams.

Changeability

Radio box, with three entries changeable, frozen and add only. Indicates whether instances of this end of the attributed may be: i) created and deleted by the source after the target instance is created; ii) not created or deleted by the source after the target instance is created; or iii) created but not deleted after the target instance is created.

Tip

This is entirely related to associations as used in the realization of a solution, and is not relevant to use case diagrams.

Visibility

Radio box, with three entries public, protected and private. Indicates whether navigation to this end may be by: i) any classifier; ii) only the source classifier and its children; or iii) only by the source classifier.

Tip

This is entirely related to associations as used in the realization of a solution, and is not relevant to use case diagrams.

15.6. Generalization

Generalization is a relationship between two use cases or two actors. Where A is a generalization of B, it means A describes more general behavior and B a more specific version of that behavior.

Examples for a travel agent sales system might be the use case for making a booking as a generalization of the use case for making a flight booking and a salesman actor being a generalization of a supervisor actor (since supervisors can also act as salesmen, but not vice versa).

Generalization is analogous to class inheritance within OO programming.

Note

It is easy to confuse extends relationships between use cases with generalization. However extends is about augmenting a use case's behavior at a specific point. Generalization is about specializing the behavior throughout the use case.

Within the UML metamodel, Generalization is a sub-class of Relationship.

Generalization is represented as an arrow with white filled head from the specialized use case or actor to the generalized use case or actor (see Figure 15.1. Possible artifacts on a use case diagram.).

15.6.1. Generalization Details Tabs

The details tabs that are active for associations are described in Table 15.13. Details tabs for generalization.

Table 15.13. Details tabs for generalization

TabMeaning
ToDoItem

Standard tab.

Properties

See Table 15.14. Property tool bar for diagram and Table 15.15. Property fields for generalization below.

Documentation

Standard tab.

Style

Standard tab

Note

The values for the bounds of the generalization appear to have no meaning. Changing them has no effect on the diagram. This is sensible behavior, given the generalization is tied to a particular actor and use case.

Source

Standard tab. You would not expect to generate any code for an association end, but this tab contains the name of the generalization.

Note

This is probably not the correct thing to do for good code generation, and will need to be changed in future versions of ArgoUML.

Constraints

Standard tab. In the UML metamodel, Generalization has the following standard constraints defined.

  • complete. Applied to a set of generalizations with the same discriminator (see Section 16.13) and same parent, indicating that an instance of the parent must be an instance of one of those children.

    Where there is only one discriminator, this implies the parent must be abstract.

    Tip

    The point of this constraint is to indicate that within the design, no more children are expected to be created for this parent. If more are created, the implication is that there will be significant rework required within the design.

  • disjoint. Applied to a set of generalizations indicates and instance of the parent must be an instance of no more than one of the children within the set.

    Note

    This is the default semantics of generalization

  • incomplete. The converse of complete indicating that within a set of generalizations of the same parent sharing the same discriminator, an instance of the parent need not be an instance of a child within the set (there is no guarantee such an instance exists)

    This implies the parent must be concrete.

    Tip

    The point of this constraint is to indicate that within the design, more children may be created for this parent. If more are created, the implication is that there should be no significant rework required within the design.

  • overlapping. The inverse f disjoint. Applied to a set of generalizations indicates an instance of one child in the set may simultaneously be an instance of another child within the set (although this is not guaranteed).

Tagged Values

Standard tab. In the UML metamodel, Generalization has the following standard tagged values defined.

  • derived (from the superclass, ModelElement). Values true, meaning the generalization is redundant—it can be formally derived from other elements, or false meaning it cannot.

    Note

    Derived generalizations still have their value in analysis to introduce useful names or concepts, and in design to avoid re-computation.

Note

The UML Element metaclass from which all other artifacts are derived includes the tagged element documentation which is handled by the documentation tab under ArgoUML

15.6.2. Generalization Properties

The property tab tool bar for associations is described in Table 15.14. Property tool bar for diagram.

Table 15.14. Property tool bar for diagram

ButtonIconMeaning
Go up

Navigate up through the package structure of the model. For a generalization this will be the package containing the generalization.

Go back

Navigate back to the previous artifact.

Warning

This feature is currently broken within ArgoUML and there is no guarantee where (if anywhere) this button will take you.

Go forward

Navigate forward to the next artifact.

Warning

This feature is currently broken within ArgoUML and there is no guarantee where (if anywhere) this button will take you.

Delete

This deletes the selected generalization from the model.

Warning

This is a deletion from the model not just the diagram. To delete a generalization from the diagram, but keep it within the model, use the main menu Edit/Remove From Diagram (Ctrl-R).

The fields on the property tab for generalizations are described in Table 15.15. Property fields for generalization.

Table 15.15. Property fields for generalization

FieldMeaning
Name

Text box. The name of the generalization.

Tip

It is quite common to leave generalizations unnamed in use case analysis.

Note

ArgoUML does not enforce any naming convention for associations.

Note

There is no representation of the stereotype of a generalization on the diagram.

Stereotype

Drop down selector. Generalization is provided by default with the UML standard stereotype, (implementation. ArgoUML also provides the additional stereotypes, machine, organization and person. The stereotype is shown between « and » above or across the generalization.

Tip

Stereotyping generalization does not have great value on a use case diagram. The standard stereotype is about implementation, and suited to the use of generalization on class diagrams.

Navigate Stereotype

icon. If a stereotype has been selected, this will navigate you to the stereotype property panel (see Section 14.4).

Discriminator

Text box. The name of a discriminator for the specialization. UML 1.3 allows grouping of specializations into a number of sets, on the basis of this value.

Tip

The empty string “” is a valid entry (and the default) for this field. The discriminator is only of practical use in cases of multiple inheritance. An example is discussed in the section covering generalization on class diagrams (see Section 16.13). There is little point in use this with a use case diagram.

Namespace

Text box. Records the namespace for the generalization. This is the package hierarchy.

Button 1 click on the entry will take you to the package defining this namespace (or the model for the top level namespace).

Parent

Text box. Records the use case or actor that is the parent in this relationship, i.e. the more general end of the relationship. Button 1 click on this entry will take you to that use case or actor. Button 2 click will give a pop up menu, with a single entry, Open which will also navigate to that use case or actor.

Child
